author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, it says so right in the first line of the abstract of EIP-4399

author: sky.cactus
content: The naming choice is *very* intentional, because we want to be very clear to developers that the value is *known* prior to the block.

author: sky.cactus
content: While this isn't a consensus thing, it is strongly encouraged to follow the `PREVRANDAO` naming convention to protect users.

author: sky.cactus
content: It matters a lot that the Solidity devs and various tooling devs name it `PREVRANDAO`, but I think there is still value for consistency across the ecosystem since a lot of tools just copy/paste huge chunks of the go-ethereum source code.

author: sky.cactus
content: Especially lists of things (like opcodes) are likely to just be wholesale copied.

author: finbob
content:
Here's an update on the issue, for anyone who was wondering:
I got some great diagnostics on the inclusion distance from pawan of sigma prime.
His suspicion is that beaconcha.in is listing the higher value of inclusion distance if the attestation was included in multiple blocks
We did track an attestation of mine that shows inclusion distance of 6 on beaconcha.in and found it was in fact included in the next block!
He explained: yeah, so an attestation can be included in multiple aggregates and those aggregates can make it to multiple blocks. Only the lowest inclusion distance is considered for the reward
So looks like a purely cosmetic thing and the beaconchain guys are checking it now

author: 0x2e
content:
we have identified the issue, we are processing batches of slots in the opposite direction (i.e ascending instead of descending), causing the highest inclusion distances to be picked over the smallest one. we are currently working on a fix.
thanks for the detailed report which allowed us to identify the issue in a quick manner!
